title: Share first, think later: When 'citizen journalism' crosses ethical lines
content: Photographing and sharing images of tragic accidents on social media is “citizen journalism at its worst” and highlights the urgent need to focus on digital education across the nation, according to experts in communication and human behaviour. The issue came to light once again following a recent fatal traffic accident in which a motorcyclist died on the spot. After the accident, graphic photos were shared extensively via WhatsApp. This had also happened some months ago when footage of another fatal accident, that involved a car losing control, made the rounds on social media. Prof. Anton Grech, clinical chairman of Mental Health Services, explained that while human curiosity in the case of unusual or dramatic situations is normal – a phenomenon known as rubbernecking – social media amplified this. These actions – of taking and sharing images of tragic situations – were a reflection of a larger situation, he said. Before social media existed there were ‘celebrities’ and ‘spectators’. Social media brought with it a shift in which many people wanted to be protagonists. This was happening in a virtual environment that is saturated with content and, in which, in order to be seen and stand out, the content has to be attention-grabbing. “In parallel with this, we are losing respect for the society around us. We saw this in a recent case when a man was threatening to jump off the Valletta bastions,” he said, referring to the 2021 case when onlookers urged a man to jump from the edge of a Valletta bastion, with many filming the ordeal. “Many people seize all opportunities to gain this recognition without respect for others,” he said, adding that there was an urgent need to educate people on this matter. Prof. Brenda Murphy, a media and gender expert and founder of NGO Mediating Women, agreed that there was the urgent need for more media education – in schools and beyond – through curriculum and public campaigns. “This is a public education issue – we need to re-establish digital boundaries. We need to remind people that our duty of care doesn’t disappear when we are online,” she said. Such cases, she said, were “citizen journalism at its worst” as they offered “a great snapshot of the widening gaps in ‘news production’”. “Journalists and editors are trained, educated, bound by professional regulation – citizens operate without any of these guardrails. While citizen journalism was lauded as a great liberator for information – this is an example of a great backfire,” she said. A deeply problematic phenomenon Murphy explained that the sharing of such images was a “deeply problematic phenomenon” that reflects multiple pressures converging at the moment. From a digital culture perspective, she said, we are living in a world where everything is documented, and the boundary between private and public is becoming increasingly eroded. “In the case of tragic moments, there seems to be an underlying belief that if something shocking happens, it should be recorded and shared. The algorithms that drive social media amplify this. They reward visibility, and sadly that includes tragic events,” she said. Then there was the conversation on media ethics.  “We may have the capacity to capture something digitally, but that doesn’t mean we should. Sharing media content has become so normalised it completely breaches the private-public boundary. We need to be mindful that sharing a traumatic event compounds trauma – not just for the family and friends but the wider community is impacted too. We cannot justify this ‘norm drift’ by saying ‘it’s already out there, so it’s ok to repost’,” she said.

title: Tributes pour in for two men who tragically died in separate accidents
content: Tributes have poured in on social media for two men who tragically lost their lives in separate accidents on Saturday. Paul Xuereb, a 67-year-old man from Żebbuġ, died after he was crushed by his own truck in Ħal Far’s industrial estate on Saturday morning. Later on that day, 43-year-old Charlo Calleja from Senglea died after he lost control of his motorbike and crashed on the Senglea seafront.  As news of their deaths spread, friends and relatives shared photos, messages of remembrance, and heartfelt condolences online. Many expressed their shock and grief at the sudden loss of both men. Paul Xuereb Paul Xuereb, more commonly known as Pawlu, used to work with cargo company White Brothers Limited. The company expressed its sorrow in a Facebook post, saying they were “deeply saddened” by the news of his death. “When Paul was part of our team, he was a valued colleague who contributed significantly during his time with us. On behalf of everyone at White Brothers Ltd, we extend our heartfelt condolences to his family and loved ones during this difficult time,” the company wrote. Two of his nephews, each shared a poem commemorating Paul's life, attached with a photo of Paul standing next to a tractor. “Kulħadd jaf li kont ġenwin, Raġel b’valuri, dejjem sinċier u fin (Everyone knows you were genuine, A man of values, always sincere and kind),” one of them wrote.  Many people described Calleja as having a "heart of gold" and a "sweet and natural spirit" Another friend reminisced about their many conversations while sitting on their motorbikes, even as recently as the day before the accident. Someone else posted on their page a picture of Calleja smiling with the caption: “You had a heart of gold, but life can be cruel to us. You will always be in our hearts." "You were one of my best and loyal friends. Fly high, till we meet again," another friend wrote.

title: Rider injured in hit-and-run is told tunnel cameras don’t work
content: A scooter rider injured in a hit-and-run crash in the Regional Road tunnels earlier this month is struggling to track down the driver, after being told that none of the tunnel cameras work. Giuseppe Di Dio, a 22-year-old Sicilian who works as a DJ and event organiser, was riding his Vespa 300 on July 2 at around 12.30pm when he was hit. As he entered the tunnel heading towards Swieqi, he says a van crossed into his lane, cut him off and crashed into him, knocking him off his Vespa. “I feel super lucky to tell the story. It hurt a lot. When I was on the floor, I could feel my burns,” he told Times of Malta. Shocked by the impact, Di Dio said he could not identify the van but recalled opening his eyes to see the driver standing over him. According to Di Dio, the man looked South Asian and was wearing a blue shirt. He believes he was driving a delivery van but is unsure which company the van belonged to. “He came over, checked I was alive, told me nothing and rushed off,” he said. “I know if I saw him, I would recognise him.” Thankfully, other drivers stopped to help Di Dio. He was taken to Mater Dei Hospital, where he said he had to wait between six to seven hours before being seen. “That was horrible. I couldn’t take it anymore and began to scream out in pain, and only then did they see me,” he said. He was initially told he had minor injuries and was prescribed painkillers. But after several days, his wounds became increasingly painful and doctors at Saint James Hospital later confirmed they were infected. Alongside the physical injuries, Di Dio said his motorbike was damaged and he incurred around €4,000 in expenses for medical treatment, medications, transport and missed work. “I want a refund for the damages but the most important thing is I want to find out who hit me to avoid future accidents,” he said.  After being treated, Di Dio filed a police report. He hoped CCTV footage from the tunnel would help identify the van. But he said police informed him that the security cameras inside the Ta’ Giorni tunnels do not work. “It’s insane. The policeman told me that none of the cameras they have for the tunnels work,” he said. “I told them that it is impossible but they told me again that none of them work.” In 2020, the government launched a €10 million project to upgrade Malta’s major tunnels, including Ta’ Giorni, which included the installation of security cameras. When asked if the cameras were working on the day of the incident, the transport ministry said: “The Traffic Control Centre did not have CCTV coverage in the mentioned area on the 2nd of July 2025.” The ministry did not answer questions about whether the cameras are operational. Police confirmed that a report on the accident had been filed and investigations are ongoing. In 2022, a Transport Malta spokesperson told Times of Malta that tunnel cameras were linked to the authority’s traffic control centre, and used for both congestion monitoring and automatic incident detection.

title: Husband of injured nurse thanks donors as fundraiser hits €70,000 in two days
content: A crowdfunding campaign for a nurse left in a coma after a car crash that killed her unborn baby has raised more than €70,000 in two days. Tonamol Baby, 28, was five months pregnant when she was struck by a car while crossing the road to start her shift as a nurse at Mount Carmel Hospital on July 16. She lost her baby and has been in hospital ever since, while her 34-year-old husband Tom Jacob spends his days by her side, far from their home in Kerala, India. Tom turned to Times of Malta to share the couple’s story as he set up a crowdfunding campaign for an air ambulance to take her home.  The cost of the medical flight is around €20,000 and the hospital costs would be at least another €30,000.  Tom daily arrives at the neurosurgical ward at Mater Dei Hospital at 8am to sit by the bedside of his wife of three years, staying until he leaves for work at 6pm. He is employed as a sommelier with the db Group. He thanked everyone who contributed, including the db Group and “the db family”, the Healthmark team (Tona’s employers), the Kerala federations and Tonamol’s friends. “Words cannot fully express our gratitude. To each and every person who contributed, shared our story, or kept us in their thoughts, thank you from the bottom of our hearts. “Your kindness has given us hope and strength during one of the most difficult times of our lives. We assure you that all of you will be remembered in our prayers always. And we kindly ask you to continue keeping us in yours, more than anything, we need your prayers,” he said. On the day of the accident, Tom was having a cup of tea at the couple’s home in Buġibba when a friend called him with the news about his wife’s accident.  As she crossed the road, a car struck her right pelvic bone and, as she fell to the ground, her head hit a bollard. When Tom arrived at the hospital, he did not recognise his wife at first. Since then, however, he has seen an improvement and hopes she can recover at home in Kerala, surrounded by family. “I will be with her for a couple of months. Then, I hope, she will be okay and I will bring her back with me,” Tom said.

content: Today, at around 1530hrs, the Police were informed of a traffic accident in Hompesch Street, Fgura.Preliminary investigations showed that a collision occurred between a Toyota Corolla driven by a 23-year-old woman from Zabbar and an Audi Q3 driven by a 77-year-old man from Marsascala.In the Toyota there was also a 71-year-old woman residing in Zabbar while in the Audi there were also two women aged 76 and 42 years, both residing in Marsascala, and two boys aged 14 and 11 years.Members of the Civil Protection Department and a medical team were called to the scene and ambulances took all the persons to Mater Dei Hospital for treatment.Unfortunately, the 71-year-old woman was certified dead a short while later while the 23-year-old woman is in serious condition, the 77-year-old man and the 76-year-old woman were certified to have sustained grievous injuries.The condition of the other persons is still pending.Magistrate Dr Ian Farrugia LL.D was informed of the case and appointed an inquiry.Police investigations into this incident are ongoing.

title: One dead in collision involving PM’s parents; George Abela and wife 'stable'
content: Updated 6.35 pm  A woman died and another is in a critical condition following a crash involving Robert Abela's mother and father. The Prime Minister's parents – former president George Abela and Margaret Abela – were among several people hospitalised following a head-on collision between two cars in Fgura on Sunday afternoon. Shortly after the accident, Prime Minister Robert Abela said his mother and father were in a stable condition in hospital. In a statement, police said the individuals were certified as "grievous". In a statement, the police said the 71-year-old woman from Żabbar was pronounced dead shortly after the incident.  A 23-year-old woman who was driving the vehicle is in a critical condition. She is also from Żabbar. The crash, between a Toyota Corolla and an Audi Q3, happened at around 3.30 pm on Triq Hompesh, the busy Fgura road leading to Żabbar.  The police said the Civil Protection Department were needed on site.  Magistrate Ian Farrugia is leading an inquiry into the crash, alongside police investigations.

title: Motorcyclist hospitalised following Sliema collision
content:
A motorcyclist was taken to Mater Dei Hospital following a traffic collision in Sliema.
The accident took place at around 11:45am when a car driven by a 71 year old man collided with the motorcycle.
Medical personnel provided assistance at the scene before the 34 year old motorcyclist was taken to Mater Dei Hospital by ambulance.

title: Former president George Abela and his wife discharged from hospital
content: Former president George Abela and his wife Margaret, who suffered serious injuries following a traffic accident a week ago, have been discharged from hospital. The couple, who are also the parents of Prime Minister Robert Abela, were discharged late last week and are now “recovering slowly at home”, a spokesperson for the Department of Information said. They were amongst others injured in a head-on collision between a Toyota Corolla and an Audi Q3 on July 27 at 3.30 pm on Triq Hompesh, the busy Fgura road leading to Żabbar. A 71-year-old woman from Żabbar involved in the collision was pronounced dead shortly after the incident. Her 23-year-old daughter was also in a critical condition but has since been discharged. Besides George and Margaret Abela, three others were in the Audi: a 42-year-old woman and two boys aged 14 and 11. George Abela, 77, served as president of Malta from 2009 to 2014. Before that he was a senior figure in the Labour Party, serving for a time as deputy leader. He was also a candidate for the role of party leader in 2008. The week between July 23 and 29 was the deadliest week on Malta’s roads in at least 25 years, with multiple fatalities reported.

title: Breathalyser showed motorist in fatal Valletta crash was five times over limit
content: A breathalyser test on Benjamin Chetcuti, the driver involved in last month's fatal crash in Valletta showed him to be some five times above the legal limit, a court heard on Tuesday. The test returned a reading of 139.2 μg/100ml (microgrammes of alcohol per 100 ml) of breath or about five times the legal limit, Superintendent Nicholas Vella said at the compilation of evidence against Chetcuti, an AFM soldier arraigned last month. He stands accused of the involuntary homicide of Mildred Azzopardi, driving under the influence and grievously injuring Azzopardi's husband through negligence. He denies the charges. Mildred Azzopardi, 62, from Ħamrun, a mother of four, died at the scene on July 27 when Chetcuti's car ploughed into her car as she put items in the boot. The 23-year-old accused joined the AFM as a recruit in January and on June 10 had his passing out ceremony and was confirmed as a gunner. He was posted to the Maritime Squadron on July 1. Police superintendent Nicholas Vella from the Road Policing Unit testified on how the accident happened at Xatt il-Barrieri, where the Azzopardis had earlier been fishing. Vella played out footage from ten CCTV cameras, explaining that the accused drove around Fort St Elmo initially at 36km/hr. His Subaru Impresa could then be seen at a speed of 246.33/m in nine seconds, meaning an average speed of 98 km/hr. The superintendent said Alfred Azzopardi, the victim's husband, was already in their Ford Fiesta while Mildred was putting some stuff away in the boot when the crash took place. CCTV footage taken from the offices of shipping companies in the area showed the Subaru Impresa arriving at a high speed before the driver lost control and it swerved, hitting Mildred Azzopardi' car first. Azzopardi died on the spot.  Medicolegal expert Mario Scerri testified that Mildred Azzopardi sustained several bone fractures and internal haemorrhage. Her husband suffered  grievous injuries and was in intensive care for a while. He added that Chetcuti tested negative for drugs. His urine sample was sent to another expert for further testing. Medicolegal experts Ali Sarfraz and David Pisani took the witness stand and testified jointly on the findings of the post-mortem examination which showed that Mildred Azzopardi suffered multiple injuries. An eyewitness also took the stand on Tuesday morning. Reeves Cini explained that at the time of the incident he was at the nearby Siege Bell Memorial. “When I arrived on site I found Benjamin,” the witness said, clarifying that he knew the accused from the time the latter worked in Valletta. The road had already been closed. The witness said he feared the worst since his grandfather owned a boathouse in the area. He asked Chectuti if he wanted something to drink, and ran up to his home and got him a soft drink from the fridge. Chetcuti told him: “I was coming from Pixxkerija (fishmarket) side when I lost control of the vehicle and crashed into the cars.”

title: Collision between motorcycle and car in Għaxaq
content: Yesterday, at around 1800hrs, the Police were informed of a traffic accident in Triq Dawret Ħal Għaxaq, Għaxaq.Preliminary investigations by the Police found that there was a collision between a Volvo XC60 that was being driven by a 42-year-old man from Għaxaq and a Malaguti Madison motorcycle that was being driven by a 29-year-old Brazilian man from Zurrieq.A medical team was called on site and an ambulance took the motorcyclist to Mater Dei Hospital for treatment where he was later certified to have sustained grievous injuries.Police investigations are ongoing.

title: Three fatal traffic accidents within a few hours
content: Updated. A motorcyclist died in a crash in Pieta' and a woman was fatally injured in Valletta on Sunday evening in the second and third fatal traffic accidents of a tragic day. Earlier another woman died in a car crash in Fgura which involved the prime minister's parents, who were hospitalised. The accident involving the motorcyclist happened at 7.30pm in Marina Street, Pieta’ and involved a 58-year-old man from Żejtun. He lost control of his Honda motorcycle, crashed into a pavement and fell off, police said.  An ambulance crew administered first aid but he died shortly after being admitted to hospital. The second accident  occurred at 10pm when a woman was hit by a car in a freak accident at Ta' Liesse, Valletta close to the fast ferry quay.   The police said a collision occurred between a Subaru Impreza driven by a 23-year-old man from Paola and a Ford Fiesta which was stopped by the side of the road. The woman, 62 of Hamrun, was trapped between the two vehicles. A 69-year-old man who was in the Fiesta was also injured. The woman died on the spot.  Magisterial inquiries are under way.

title: Your life was cut too soon': Mildred Azzopardi killed in tragic Valletta crash
content: A mother-of-four who died when she was trapped between two cars in a crash on Sunday has been named as Mildred Azzopardi.  The 62-year-old from Ħamrun was at Ta' Liesse in Valletta, when a Subaru Impreza driven by a 23-year-old man from Paola collided with a Ford Fiesta which was stopped by the side of the road. She was trapped between the two cars at the time and died on the spot. In a heartfelt message shared on Facebook, her sister, Frida Farrugia, expressed grief at the way her sister's “life was cut short too soon”.  “You will always be remembered by us, your siblings, as a guiding light and loved till we meet again. You will be sorely missed…. I love you to death my dearest sister. Look after your children, your husband and your little grandchildren,” her sister wrote. The woman had been fishing shortly before the accident on Sunday at 10pm.   She was the third person to die on the roads in three separate accidents on Sunday. Earlier that evening, at about 7.30pm, in Marina Street, Pieta’ a 58-year-old man from Żejtun lost control of his Honda motorcycle, crashed into a pavement and fell off. He died soon after. In the afternoon, a 71-year-old woman died and another is in a critical condition following a two-car crash involving Robert Abela's mother and father – former president George Abela and Margaret Abela. The crash happened at around 3.30pm on Triq Hompesh, the busy Fgura road leading to Żabbar. A 23-year-old woman from Żabbar who was driving the vehicle is in a critical condition. Prime Minister Robert Abela later said his parents were in a stable condition in hospital.

title: Man dies after being hit by a bus at Floriana Park and Ride
content: A 63-year-old man from Naxxar has died after being hit by a bus at the Floriana Park and Ride facility.  The accident happened at around 1.45 pm on Tuesday. He was taken to Mater Dei Hospital by ambulance, where he was being treated for serious injuries, police said. He was later pronounced dead. It is the fifth fatal accident on Malta's roads in just four days.  On Saturday, a 27-year-old motorcyclist was killed when his bike was involved in a crash with a BMW in Pembroke in the early hours of the morning.  The following day a woman died in a head-on crash in Fgura that also involved former president George Abela and his wife. A motorcyclist died in Pieta a few hours later.  And on Sunday evening  mother of four, Mildred Azzopardi, died when she was trapped between two cars in a crash on Sunday evening. A 23-year-old soldier has been charged with involuntary homicide for Azzopardi's death.

title: Zejtun traffic accident
content: This morning, at around 0815 hrs, the Police were informed of a traffic accident in Triq tal-Barrani, Żejtun.Preliminary investigations showed that a collision occurred between a Peugeot Tweet driven by a 66-year-old man from Zabbar and a Kawazaki motorcycle driven by a 30-year-old woman who lives in Marsaxlokk.A medical team was called on site and an ambulance took both drivers to Mater Dei Hospital for treatment. title: Two people left with serious injuries in separate traffic accidents
content: Two people were left with serious injuries in separate traffic accidents on Monday. The first incident occurred at around 3.30pm on Aldo Moro Street in Marsa, when a Kymco motorcycle ridden by a 67-year-old man from Tarxien and a BMW I3 car driven by a 79-year-old Sliema woman were involved in a collision. The man was treated at the scene before being taken to Mater Dei Hospital. The second incident took place at around 5pm on Triq il-Mosta in Lija, when a collision occurred between a Mercedes A180 driven by a 28-year-old man from Birkirkara and a Renault Megane driven by a 36-year-old Naxxar woman. title: Man grievously injured in traffic accident
content: A 28-year-old man who lives in Għargħur, at around 0745hrs, was taken to Mater Dei Hospital because he was injured in a traffic accident in Triq ix-Xatt Ta’ Xbiex, Ta’ Xbiex.Preliminary investigations showed that the man was hit by a Toyota IQ, which was being driven by a 52-year-old Italian man residing in Gzira.The man was assisted by a medical team, taken to hospital by ambulance and certified to have sustained grievous injuries.Police investigations are ongoing.

title: Ex-footballer Alfred Azzopardi 'fighting for life' after crash that killed wife
content: The son of former Malta footballer Alfred Azzopardi says he is fighting for his life after a car crash that killed his wife on Sunday.  Cain Azzopardi paid a heartbreaking tribute to his mother, Mildred, who was crushed to death when a Subaru Imprezza crashed into the parked family car. The driver of the Subaru Impreza, 23-year-old soldier Benjamin Chetcuti, has been charged with involuntary homicide and drink-driving. He denies all charges. "You didn't deserve this ma after someone irresponsible took your life, we miss you so much and we keep pushing forward as dad keeps fighting for his life," Cain Azzopardi wrote on Facebook on Wednesday. "My best friend, we won't be visiting the Pyramids in Egypt together like we always wanted to. But I know you will there with me. I love you ❤️"  Another of the victim's four children, Amy Azzopardi, shared details of her funeral, which will be held at 9.15am on Saturday at the Floriana Saint Publius Church.  She asked mourners not to wear black, but instead dress in colour "preferably turquoise or orange her favourite colours". The couple had finished a fishing trip at the Valletta waterfront when the crash happened at Ta' Liesse in Valletta. Mildred Azzopardi, 62, was outside the parked Ford Fiesta while her husband Alfred Azzopardi, 69, was inside.  Alfred Azzopardi is a popular figure in Ħamrun, given his successful career as a football player with Ħamrun Spartans during their golden years in the 1980s. He played as a defender, spending over 10 years with the Spartans, helping the Reds to Premier League promotion in season 1975-76. His best years with the Spartans arrived in the 1980s as he helped his club to a league and cup double in season 1982-83 and the FA Trophy the following campaign. In season 1985-86, he helped the Reds to lift the Euro Cup. During his career, Azzopardi also donned the colours of Hibernians and was selected to represent the Malta national team, where he collected eight international caps.

title: Eight-year-old and two motorcyclists seriously injured in two traffic accidents

title: Karmenu Muscat, driving instructor who died in bus accident, was an Olympian
content: Karmenu Muscat, the Tallinja driving instructor who died on Tuesday after a bus rolled back on him, was part of Malta’s representation in the 1980 Olympics. In a tribute post to the 63-year-old, the Maltese Olympic Committee said Muscat’s Olympian legacy will not be forgotten. “Karmenu proudly represented Malta in cycling at the 1980 Moscow Olympic Games,” the MOC said, adding they are “deeply saddened” by his passing. Muscat was among only a handful of Maltese athletes in the Games held 45 years ago.  As part of the cycling team, Muscat participated in the team trials where Malta finished in the 20th position out of 23 nations, beating Libya, Cameroon and Ethiopia. The MOC sent their condolences to Muscat’s family and loved ones. Muscat, who was a bus driving instructor, was caught between a back-rolling bus and a wall during the Tuesday afternoon incident at the Floriana Park and Ride.  A medical team was on site and Muscat was taken immediately to Mater Dei Hospital but died shortly afterwards. In a Facebook post, Malta's public transport operator Tallinja said the organisation was "deeply saddened by the tragic loss of our colleague and dear friend, Karmenu Muscat, who passed away today in a devastating accident". The company described him as someone many looked up to for his “patience, professionalism, and dedication”.

title: Drunk cab driver was waiting for passengers before crash into salon, court hears
content: A cab driver who was over the legal alcohol limit when he crashed into a Santa Venera hair salon told police he had been waiting for passengers, a court has heard. Abdi Salaan Mahamad Abditon Ali had a reading of 107.3 micrograms of alcohol per 100 ml breath, when the legal limit for cab drivers is zero, after the crash into Marica’s Salon, on Cannon Road, on August 7. A court on Monday heard that he gave a statement to police, in which he said he was waiting for passengers just before the collision. "Thank God no one requested a cab… It could have resulted in fatalities,” police inspector Nathan Bugeja told the court.   The 42-year-old Somali national stands accused of driving in a negligent, dangerous and reckless manner, causing damage to third property, and driving under influence. He denies the charges. The salon was still closed at the time of the incident and there were no injuries. A police constable testified about receiving a call regarding the collision, with the initial information stating that the vehicle had crashed into a “house”. When the witness got onsite, he found the owner, Marica Baldacchino, who had not seen the incident. The witness went to Mater Dei Hospital where he spoke to the driver. He returned back when another constable was subjecting the driver to the a breathalyzer test. The constable underlined that a cab driver’s limit is 0 μg/100ml. During Monday’s sitting, the prosecution and defence made submissions on bail. Police inspector Bugeja objected due to the seriousness of the crime.  Bugeja also highlighted that although the man’s address on his official documents and the charge sheet state that he lives in St Paul’s Bay, the police accompanied him to a Ħamrun address to collect his passport. Defence lawyer Francesca Zarb counter-argued that the defendant has been in Malta since 2008 and this was his first brush with the law. He was granted subsidiary protection and has a residence permit. The lawyer observed that the court as presided hears cases on traffic collisions and argued that individuals with the same charges are brought before it under summons not under arrest. Zarb also argued that whether the man is granted bail or otherwise, the amount of damages would not be affected. Bugeja rebutted the argument stating that usually collisions do not involve third parties, nor do they involve damages running into thousands of euros. While an exact figure was not given during Monday’s sitting, the damages sustained are between €10,000 to €15,000. These will be confirmed once the salon owner takes the stand. The police inspector also added that the man poses a risk to the public. Zarb observed that two of Ali’s friends were present in the courtroom, with one of them willing to host him. The friend told the court that he came to Malta in 2006 and has known the accused for the past eight years. The court then asked the accused whether he held a bank account, signalling it was willing to grant bail, only if a bank guarantee could be made. After establishing that Ali lacked a bank account with a local bank through which he could guarantee at least €10,000 in favour of the victim, the court denied the man bail. In its decision, the court held that it does not have the peace of mind he would be able to satisfy all conditions otherwise imposed by the court in a bail decree, even though at this stage, the man is presumed innocent until proven guilty. The case continues later this month. Magistrate Victor Axiak presided.Police inspectors Nathan Bugeja and Rachel Aquilina prosecuted.Lawyer Francesca Zarb appeared for the accused.Lawyers Zack Esmail and Kaylie Borg appeared parte civile.

title: Driver was drunk when cab crashed into hairdresser's salon, court told
content: The motorist who was behind the wheel of a cab that crashed into a hairdresser's shop on Thursday morning was drunk, a court heard during his arraignment on Sunday. Police Inspector Nathan Bugeja told Magistrate Gianella Camilleri Busuttil that the motorist, 42-year-old Somali Abdi Salaan Mahammad Abditon, suffered slight injuries when he lost control of the car and crashed into the salon on Cannon Road, Sta Venera. A breathalyser test in hospital showed an alcohol level of over 100 when he should not have had any alcoholic drink, being a cab driver.  No one was injured in the incident, which happened at about 8am and was recorded on CCTV.  The hairdresser avoided injury because she happened to be outside feeding cats. The defence requested bail, with the legal aid lawyer arguing that his client had not had any previous court cases and did not know the witnesses. The prosecution opposed the request, pointing out that this was a serious case, and the accused had told the police that he wished to speak to the shop's owner. Bail was denied.

title: Companies rally to help Sta Venera hair salon after car crash
content: A number of companies have offered to help the owner of a Santa Venera hair salon to clear up the wreckage and debris for free after a car smashed through the shop’s glass doors. The salon was extensively damaged on Thursday morning after a Y-plate cab ploughed into the salon’s glass doors at speed, smashing through furniture and stopping just in front of the reception desk. CCTV footage showed the accident left shattered glass, broken furniture and other debris. On Friday, JA Transport left a message on popular Facebook group Are You Being Served to reach out to the owner of Marica’s Salon offering the company’s services for free, saying they were available to help her “get back on her feet as quickly as possible”. Maverick Baldacchino, the hair salon owner’s son, replied: “May there be more people like you in the world”. Other companies quickly followed JA Transport’s initiative. JG Cleaning Services offered their help for free while Bieb u Għatba turnkey project management company said “let us know how we can give you a helping hand”. Amai beauty salon offered the hairdresser a work station.  The companies’ “heartwarming” offer for help was met with a considerable response with many commenting on the “positive and amazing gesture” and remarking that “there are not many people of goodwill left like you”. The salon on Canon Road was empty at the time of the accident and the owner, Marica Baldacchino, happened to be out feeding stray cats. The driver, a 42-year-old man from Somalia who resides in St Paul's Bay sustained slight injuries. In a social media post, the hairdresser's son Maverick wrote the salon would be open for business as usual on Friday, the morning after the accident, despite the damage sustained to the outlet.

title: Cab ploughs into hairdresser's salon in Santa Venera
content: Updated 9.56am A taxi crashed into a hairdresser's salon in Santa Venera on Thursday morning. The car, a Y-plate vehicle, ploughed into Marica's Salon on Cannon Road at around 8am, with police and Civil Protection Department officers on the scene shortly after. A visit to the site showed the car almost completely inside the salon after smashing through the glass at the front of the business. Nobody is believed to have been inside the salon at the time. The driver of the vehicle is believed to have been taken to hospital after sustaining injuries in the crash. The salon describes itself as being in Santa Venera, and is located on the border between the locality and Ħamrun. More to follow.

title: Woman in hospital after overturning car in San Ġwann valley
content: A 25-year-old woman was taken to hospital on Saturday morning after she overturned her car while driving through the San Ġwann valley. The woman, who lives in Swieqi, was driving a Volkswagen Polo on Triq il-Pellikan at around 7.30am when she lost control of the vehicle and overturned it. No information about her medical condition was available at the time of writing, but a police spokesperson said her injuries were not critical. The road was temporarily closed to traffic while officers cleared the scene.

title: Food courier injured in Mġarr accident
content: A food courier was seriously injured when he lost control of his motorcycle and crashed at Mosta Road, Mġarr, late on Sunday. The police said the 33-year-old Indian national, a resident in San Ġwann fell off his motorcycle at about 7pm. He was given first aid by an ambulance crew and hospitalised in a serious condition.  It was the second serious incident involving a food courier on Sunday. Earlier in the day, a Nepalese courier died when his motorcycle was hit by a car driven by an underage motorist in Sta Venera.

title: Underage driver set to be arraigned over Sunday's fatal crash
content: A motorist who hit and killed a food courier before crashing into three parked cars is due to be taken to court at noon on Monday. He is expected to face charges of involuntary homicide, reckless driving leading to the death of the 42-year-old motorcyclist from Nepal, driving when he was too young to hold a driving licence, and running away from the scene of the crash. The young man was driving his father's Maserati Levante when the crash happened at 5.20am in Psaila Street, Sta Venera. He was arrested several hours later, along with an 18-year-old woman, a passenger who also ran away from the scene. A third young woman, also a passenger, was arrested minutes after the crash, close to the scene of the crash, having suffered injuries.

title: Fundraiser for hit-and-run victim hits over €11,000 in less than 24 hours
content: A fundraiser for a food courier killed in a hit-and-run on Sunday has raised over €11,000 in less than 24 hours. Khim Bahadur Pun, 42, from Nepal, was carrying his Wolt delivery bag when his motorcycle was hit in  Birkirkara at 5.25am. An underage driver, who was arrested after fleeing the scene, is to be arraigned on Monday in connection with the crash.  The Non-Resident Nepali Association (NRNA) said there had been "huge support" for a fundraiser it set up to help the father-of-three's family and to cover the funeral costs in Nepal.   Khanal described the Nepalese community as "one big family", and said the loss of Pun had deeply affected them all. He said he was deeply moved and grateful to see such "overwhelming" support for Pun. "This generosity not only reflects the kindness and compassion of people here in Malta and beyond, but also gives strength and hope to Khim's family during this incredibly difficult time. It's a powerful reminder that humanity transcends borders, and when we come together, we can truly make a difference." A 17-year-old from Qormi, is due to be taken to court on Monday afternoon.  The motorist was driving his father's Maserati Levante when the crash happened at 5.20am in Psaila Street, Sta Venera. He was arrested several hours later, along with an 18-year-old passenger who also ran away from the scene.  A third passenger, an 18-year-old woman also from Qormi, was arrested minutes after the crash, close to the scene of the crash, having suffered injuries.

title: Pedestrian injured in Floriana
content: A 72-year-old pedestrian was seriously injured when he was hit by a car on National Road, Floriana. The police said the accident happened at 9am on Sunday when the elderly man was hit by a Peugeot Partner van that was being driven by a 78-year-old man from Birżebbuġa. The victim was hospitalised. The police are investigating.

title: 17-year-old arrested over fatal hit-and-run, hours after fleeing scene
content: Updated 12.30pm with more details Police have arrested an underage driver believed to have been behind the wheel of a car that killed a 42-year-old motorcyclist in a horrific hit-and-run in Birkirkara early on Sunday.  The driver, a 17-year-old boy, and an 18-year-old passenger, both from Qormi, were arrested hours after the accident, after fleeing the scene on foot.  Initial investigations suggest a Maserati Levante crashed into a Kymco motorbike driven by the victim, a 42-year-old Nepalese man, residing in Birkirkara. The incident happened at 5.20am on Triq Salvu Psaila.  Following the impact, the car crashed into three parked vehicles.  The victim was pronounced dead at the scene of the accident, while the 17-year-old car driver and two passengers left the scene.  One of the passengers, an 18-year-old girl from Mosta, was found a short distance away from the accident and was arrested. She was taken to Mater Dei Hospital, and was later certified to be suffering grievous injuries. It is not yet known if the driver and the other passenger sustained any injuries.  The Maserati is owned by the driver's father, who was also arrested by the police.

title: Hit-and-run victim named as food courier father-of-three Khim Bahadur Pun
content: Updated 5.42pm with doctors' call road safety action The 42-year-old motorcyclist who was killed in a horrific hit-and-run in Birkirkara early on Sunday morning has been named as Khim Bahadur Pun from Nepal. A father of three young children, Pun moved to Malta three years ago and was working as a food courier. He is the 18th person to have died on Malta's roads this year.  Police said the 42-year-old victim, who was residing in Birkirkara, died after a Maserati Levante crashed into the Kymco motorbike he was driving.  Following the impact, the Maserati crashed into three parked vehicles and the three people inside it fled on foot. The 17-year-old driver and his father have been arrested. In a Facebook post, the Non-Resident Nepali Association (NRNA) said they were shocked by the news of Pun's death, all due to an unfortunate road accident.   These, the NGO said, are not radical proposals - they are basic safety measures used successfully worldwide. "The father who died today, and the 17 others before him this year, deserves justice through action. Their families deserve a guarantee that no stone is left unturned so that no other family will endure this preventable heartbreak," the doctors said.

title: Friends launch fundraiser to bring home Italian tourist killed in Pembroke crash
content: The friends of a 21-year old Italian tourist who died following a motorcycle crash in Pembroke have launched an online fundraising campaign to repatriate his body. Maichol Di Nunzio from Primavalle, in the north-eastern part of Rome, crashed his Kymco Agility motorbike into a conrete barrier on Triq Sant’ Andrija early on Thursday morning. He succumbed to his injuries on Saturday. His friends describe di Nunzio as “full of life and always cheerful” but had lived a life full of hardship. He was brought up in a foster home from the age of nine together with his sister Aurora. “They grew up side by side, supporting each other and becoming a vital point of reference for one another,” fundraiser organiser Desire Di Francesco said. “Now, it is Aurora who must face the repatriation of her brother’s body to Italy,” she said, adding that Aurora does not have the financial means to cover the expenses. By Sunday morning the fundraiser had already raised over €28,700, more than half the amount requested, from around 600 donors. The GoFundMe fundraiser can be accessed here.

title: Case continues of drunk driver in Baħar iċ-Ċagħaq crash, driver granted bail
content: A woman involved in a Baħar ic-Cagħaq collision that left a motorcyclist seriously injured has been granted bail. Yoana Valentinova Gatt, a 44-year-old Bulgarian national living in St Paul’s Bay, admitted earlier this week to causing grievous bodily harm through negligence to the motorcyclist, damaging the victim’s motorcycle, driving under the influence and drink driving. She denies the reckless driving charge, and the case continues with respect to that charge. The incident took place on August 17 when Valentinova Gatt hit the motorcycle from the rear, injuring its driver, a 53-year-old Belgian national living in Gżira. Eyewitnesses who testified earlier this week explained how five men had lifted the woman’s car, which had its engine still running, to free the trapped motorcyclist. The motorcyclist was placed in the recovery position until the emergency services arrived at the scene. A breathalyser test revealed Valentinova Gatt was six times over the legal limit, with the test marking 124.9 μg/100ml (microgrammes of alcohol per 100ml breath). On Friday morning, the court granted the woman bail against a €2,000 deposit and a €10,000 personal guarantee. She was ordered to sign the bail book twice a week. Magistrate Antoine Agius Bonnici presided. Police inspector Nathan Bugeja prosecuted. Legal aid lawyer Nadya Fiott appeared for the accused.

title: Drunk driver in Baħar iċ-Ċagħaq crash pleads guilty to most charges

Yoana Valentinova Gatt, a 44-year-old Bulgarian national living in St Paul’s Bay, stands accused of causing grievous bodily harm through negligence, reckless driving, damaging the victim’s motorcycle, driving under the influence and drink driving.  She is pleading guilty to four out of five charges. A breathalyser test had revealed she was six times over the legal limit, with the test marking 124.9 μg/100ml (microgrammes of alcohol per 100ml breath). On Wednesday morning, police inspector Nathan Bugejatold the court the police were informed about a collision between a car and a motorcycle just before the exit to the roundabout at about 3:37pm. CCTV footage captured the whole accident as it happened. “The motorcycle was at the stop sign on the give way, when Gatt ran over it,” Bugeja told the court. title: Magistrate urges random alcohol, drug tests after fatal biker crash
content: A magistrate has called for random roadside alcohol and drug testing of drivers, after a fatal Senglea motorcycle crash revealed the rider had cocaine in his system. Magistrate Joe Mifsud made the recommendation following a magisterial inquiry into the June accident on Triq ix-Xatt Juan B. Azopardo. The 43-year-old motorcyclist lost control, struck a bollard and was killed on the spot. No one else was injured. Toxicology tests conducted during the autopsy found traces of cocaine in his system. In his concluding remarks, Mifsud said that “while it seems that disciplinary measures have started being taken while driving, enforcement needs to increase and officials should be conscious of their role in protecting lives”. He stressed that while discipline has never killed anyone, substance abuse has, with the victims sometimes being innocent, law-abiding citizens who suffer due to the abuse of others. The magistrate urged better coordination between the authorities and constant, rather than sporadic, law enforcement presence on the roads. He referred to a 2023 position paper co-written by NGO Doctors For Road Safety, the Maltese Association of Psychiatry and the Foundation for Welfare Services on drug-driving under the influence of psychoactive drugs.  The paper states that “the use of psychoactive drugs can result in impaired driving skills, leading to an increased risk of road traffic crashes. “It is important to note that the most common psychoactive drugs involved in driving crashes are often taken for recreational purposes, although prescription drugs such as benzodiazepines and opioids can also impair driving skills.” Mifsud endorsed each of the paper’s eight recommendations, including the introduction of a legal framework to enable random drug testing for psychoactive substances, as well as the random screening of professional drivers, such as taxi, school bus, coach and heavy machinery drivers. The paper also called for the establishment of clear guidelines regarding acceptable substance levels in the body while driving, and the review and updating of existing legislation to include penalties for the combined use of drugs and alcohol to reflect the increased risk to road safety. Many European countries allow random or targeted random roadside testing for alcohol or drugs. In the UK, Germany and Malta, the police need “reasonable suspicion” to conduct tests. The Maltese magistrate’s call comes amid a spate of serious road accidents in recent weeks, several linked to drink-driving. In July, AFM soldier Benjamin Chetcuti was allegedly five times over the alcohol limit when his car hit 62-year-old Mildred Azzopardi in Valletta, killing her and injuring her husband. The test returned a positive result of 139.2 μg/100ml when the legal limit is 22micrograms. On August 10, food courier Khim Bahadur Pun, 42, from Nepal, was killed when his motorcycle was hit by a car driven by a 17-year-old in Santa Venera. The youth fled the scene but was arrested five hours later. Police said a breathalyser test found he was over the legal alcohol limit. And earlier this month, a taxi crashed into a hair salon in Santa Venera. The owner, who was outside at the time, was unhurt. Tests showed the driver’s alcohol level exceeded 100mg.

title: Concrete action urged for road safety
content: The Nationalist Party on Thursday called for “concrete action” to address road safety in Malta as an emergency doctor slammed the situation as "unacceptable". The statements came in the wake of another accident caused by drink-driving when a car, driven by a Brazilian man, crashed head on into an oncoming bus in the opposite lane on Tower Road in Sliema. The car driver was four times over the alcohol limit.  Michael Spiteri, who was attending to the first call out of the day at just before 6am on Thursday in the wake of the Sliema accident, warned this could "have ended in tragedy". “Irresponsible drivers are putting innocent lives at risk. It is obvious that some are refusing to learn, so the only way forward is random and frequent checks, harsh penalties, and highly visible enforcement to deter this reckless behaviour. This country should act to reduce preventable injuries and deaths,” Spiteri said. In a number of proposals to address the issue, the Opposition insisted on “zero tolerance” for accidents caused by drivers who are found to be under the influence of alcohol or drugs, stronger law enforcement, harsher penalties and the introduction of a “new specific criminal offence” for causing death or grievous bodily harm due to gross negligence, recklessness and/or dangerous driving. This offence would carry a minimum penalty of five years’ effective imprisonment, rising up to life imprisonment in cases with aggravating factors, the PN said. Currently, the Police Force has 18 breathalysers, while LESA has five breathalyser kits, all of which only detect alcohol. The PN said the number of road-testing devices “must be increased” and kits that detect drugs should be added. “This is a real and serious problem on our roads,” the PN said. They also highlighted the shortage of staff allocated in the police traffic section and urged for greater investment in the police force, the traffic section and the authorities responsible for road enforcement. These proposals follow a chorus of voices from various entities calling for the introduction of random drug and alcohol tests for motorists and increased road safety.

title: Birkirkara aqueduct arch collapses after traffic accident – council
content: An aqueduct arch in Birkirkara collapsed after a traffic accident in the area, the local council said Tuesday evening, while calling for swift repair works ahead of the beginning of the new scholastic year. In a statement, the council said, “some weeks ago, one of the arches of the historic aqueduct located in our locality collapsed due to a traffic accident that occurred in the area”. While no further details about the accident were provided, in July part of the historic Wignacourt aqueduct in Mrieħel was closed off for checks after a truck hit one of the arches as it joined the Rabat road. An architect was appointed by the Superintendence of Cultural Heritage to evaluate and prepare a report on the damage, with repair works to be carried out “by the relevant authorities”, the council said.  “The council wishes to emphasise that it is not within its remit to carry out these works, nor does it hold any legal or technical responsibility for the repair of the arch”, it said. “Nevertheless, the council has been actively and continuously putting pressure and engaging to ensure that these works are undertaken as soon as possible.” The council said the pending repairs were “particularly important” due to the new school year starting later this month, with it “very aware of the traffic pressure that already exists in the area – pressure that has increased due to the closure of this arch”. It “strongly appealed” to authorities "to make every effort to ensure that the necessary works are carried out without further delay". The Birkirkara community and residents “deserve a serious and immediate solution to this inconvenience that has persisted for too long”, the council said. The aqueduct was built on the orders of Grand Master Wignacourt, for whom it is named, to carry water from springs in Dingli and Rabat to Valletta. It was inaugurated in April 1615. This is not the first time the historic structure was damaged; in August 2018, one of the arches was damaged when the driver of a large concrete-mix truck ignored traffic signs and tried to drive through, damaging the central corbel stone of the arch. The council statement was signed by mayor Desirei Grech and executive secretary Christine-Jo Mansueto.

title: Watch: The moment car crashes into Marsa building
content: Four men escaped injury when the driver lost control of his car and smashed into the facade of a building in Marsa causing some damage. The incident happened on Friday afternoon in Triq Isouard when CCTV footage captured a Mercedes driving round a corner at the top of the street, swerving across the opposite lane and crashing with some speed, climbing the pavement and into the facade of a private residence.  Just seconds earlier, a woman was walking in the street on the opposite side of the road but she stepped off the road and onto the safety of the pavement just as the car crashed into the building opposite. The Mercedes also hit the back of a Citroen parked outside the building, shoving it slightly forward. The four men climbed out of the vehicle seemingly unharmed as they surveyed the extensive damage caused both to the front of the car and to the facade. Stones were seen falling off the facade after the impact. It is not yet known if the owners of the residence were at home at the time of the accident. LESA CEO Svetlick Flores said "this is normal business for us to see a collision involving a vehicle and a building or a fence". Last month, a cab driver crashed into a hairdressing salon in Santa Venera causing more than €10,000 in damages. The driver was charged with drink driving.  This is a developing story. More to follow.

title: Two men seriously injured in separate traffic accidents
content: Two men were seriously injured in two separate traffic accidents on Saturday night.   The first accident occurred at around 11pm on the St Paul’s Roundabout, when a 69-year-old man, a resident of the area, collided with the pavement while driving his Mercedes B180, flipping his car and leaving it upside down in a field to the side of the road. The second accident occurred at around 1.30am on Triq Mikiel Anton Vassalli in Msida, when a Honda CB650 motorcycle driven by a Ta’ Xbiex man, 34, was involved in a collision with a Mazda Demio driven by a 24-year-old man from Vittoriosa. Medical staff attended both scenes, with the 69-year-old man and the motorcyclist taken to Mater Dei Hospital for further treatment, where their injuries were certified as serious. Investigations are continuing.
